string-array.name: talk_content
string-array.item: UNIT 1: WHERE ARE YOU FROM?
ˈjunət 1: wɛr ɑr ju frʌm?
James: Hello
ʤeɪmz: həˈloʊ
Lisa: Hi.
ˈlisə: haɪ.
James: How are you?
ʤeɪmz: haʊ ɑr ju?
Lisa: I\'m good. How are you?
ˈlisə: aɪm gʊd. haʊ ɑr ju?
James: Good. Do you speak English?
ʤeɪmz: gʊd. du ju spik ˈɪŋglɪʃ?
Lisa: A little. Are you American?
ˈlisə: ə ˈlɪtəl. ɑr ju əˈmɛrəkən?
James: Yes.
ʤeɪmz: jɛs.
Lisa: Where are you from?
ˈlisə: wɛr ɑr ju frʌm?
James: I\'m from California.
ʤeɪmz: aɪm frʌm ˌkæləˈfɔrnjə.
Lisa: Nice to meet you.
ˈlisə: naɪs tu mit ju.
James: Nice to meet you too.
ʤeɪmz: naɪs tu mit ju tu.
\n
UNIT 2: DO YOU SPEAK ENGLISH
ˈjunət 2: du ju spik ˈɪŋglɪʃ
Mary: Excuse me, are you American?
ˈmɛri: ɪkˈskjus mi, ɑr ju əˈmɛrəkən?
Robert: No
ˈrɑbɜrt: noʊ
Mary: Do you speak English?
ˈmɛri: du ju spik ˈɪŋglɪʃ?
Robert: A little, but not very well
ˈrɑbɜrt: ə ˈlɪtəl, bʌt nɑt ˈvɛri wɛl
Mary: How long have you been here?
ˈmɛri: haʊ lɔŋ hæv ju bɪn hir?
Robert: 2 months.
ˈrɑbɜrt: 2 mʌnθs.
Mary: What do you do for work?
ˈmɛri: wʌt du ju du fɔr wɜrk?
Robert: I\'m a student. How about you?
ˈrɑbɜrt: aɪm ə ˈstudənt. haʊ əˈbaʊt ju?
Mary: I\'m a student too.
ˈmɛri: aɪm ə ˈstudənt tu.
\n
UNIT 3: WHAT\'S YOUR NAME?
ˈjunət 3: wʌts jʊər neɪm?
John: Excuse me, what\'s your name?
ʤɑn: ɪkˈskjus mi, wʌts jʊər neɪm?
Jessica: My name is Jessica. What\'s yours?
ˈʤɛsɪkə: maɪ neɪm ɪz ˈʤɛsɪkə. wʌts jʊrz?
John: John
ʤɑn: ʤɑn
Jessica: You speak English very well.
ˈʤɛsɪkə: ju spik ˈɪŋglɪʃ ˈvɛri wɛl.
John: Thank you
ʤɑn: θæŋk ju
Jessica: Do you know what time it is?
ˈʤɛsɪkə: du ju noʊ wʌt taɪm ɪt ɪz?
John: Sure. It\'s 5:10
ʤɑn: ʃʊr. ɪts 5:10
Jessica: What did you say?
ˈʤɛsɪkə: wʌt dɪd ju seɪ?
John: I said it\'s 5:10
ʤɑn: aɪ sɛd ɪts 5:10
Jessica: Thanks.
ˈʤɛsɪkə: θæŋks.
John: You\'re welcome.
ʤɑn: jʊr ˈwɛlkəm.
\n
UNIT 4: ASKING DIRECTIONS
ˈjunət 4: ˈæskɪŋ dəˈrɛkʃənz
Amy: Hi Michael
ˈeɪmi: haɪ ˈmaɪkəl
Michael: Hi Amy. What\'s up?
ˈmaɪkəl: haɪ ˈeɪmi. wʌts ʌp?
Amy: I\'m looking for the airport. Can you tell me how to get there?
ˈeɪmi: aɪm ˈlʊkɪŋ fɔr ði ˈɛrˌpɔrt. kæn ju tɛl mi haʊ tu gɛt ðeər?
Michael: No, sorry. I don\'t know.
ˈmaɪkəl: noʊ, ˈsɑri. aɪ doʊnt noʊ.
Amy: I think I can take the subway to the airport. Do you know where the subway is?
ˈeɪmi: aɪ θɪŋk aɪ kæn teɪk ðə ˈsʌˌbweɪ tu ði ˈɛrˌpɔrt. du ju noʊ wɛr ðə ˈsʌˌbweɪ ɪz?
Michael: Sure, it\'s over there.
ˈmaɪkəl: ʃʊr, ɪts ˈoʊvər ðeər.
Amy: Where? I don\'t see it.
ˈeɪmi: wɛr? aɪ doʊnt si ɪt.
Michael: Across the street.
ˈmaɪkəl: əˈkrɔs ðə strit.
Amy: Oh, I see it now. Thanks.
ˈeɪmi: oʊ, aɪ si ɪt naʊ. θæŋks.
Michael: No problem.
ˈmaɪkəl: noʊ ˈprɑbləm.
Amy: Do you know if there\'s a restroom around here?
ˈeɪmi: du ju noʊ ɪf ðeərz ə ˈrɛˌstrum əˈraʊnd hir?
Michael: Yes, there\'s one here. It\'s in the store.
ˈmaɪkəl: jɛs, ðeərz wʌn hir. ɪts ɪn ðə stɔr.
Amy: Thank you.
ˈeɪmi: θæŋk ju.
Michael: Bye.
ˈmaɪkəl: baɪ.
Amy: Bye bye.
ˈeɪmi: baɪ baɪ.
\n
UNIT 5: I\'M HUNGRY
ˈjunət 5: aɪm ˈhʌŋgri
Thomas: Hi Sarah, how are you?
ˈtɑməs: haɪ ˈsɛrə, haʊ ɑr ju?
Sarah: Fine, how are you doing?
ˈsɛrə: faɪn, haʊ ɑr ju ˈduɪŋ?
Thomas: OK
ˈtɑməs: ˈoʊˈkeɪ
Sarah: What do you want to do?
ˈsɛrə: wʌt du ju wɑnt tu du?
Thomas: I\'m hungry. I\'d like to eat something.
ˈtɑməs: aɪm ˈhʌŋgri. aɪd laɪk tu it ˈsʌmθɪŋ.
Sarah: Where do you want to go?
ˈsɛrə: wɛr du ju wɑnt tu goʊ?
Thomas: I\'d like to go to an Italian restaurant.
ˈtɑməs: aɪd laɪk tu goʊ tu ən ɪˈtæljən ˈrɛstəˌrɑnt.
Sarah: What kind of Italian food do you like?
ˈsɛrə: wʌt kaɪnd ɑv ɪˈtæljən fud du ju laɪk?
Thomas: I like spaghetti. Do you like spaghetti?
ˈtɑməs: aɪ laɪk spəˈgɛti. du ju laɪk spəˈgɛti?
Sarah: No, I don\'t, but I like pizza.
ˈsɛrə: noʊ, aɪ doʊnt, bʌt aɪ laɪk ˈpitsə.
\n
UNIT 6: DO YOU WANT SOMETHING TO DRINK?
ˈjunət 6: du ju wɑnt ˈsʌmθɪŋ tu drɪŋk?
Susan: David, would you like something to eat?
ˈsuzən: ˈdeɪvɪd, wʊd ju laɪk ˈsʌmθɪŋ tu it?
David: No, I\'m full.
ˈdeɪvɪd: noʊ, aɪm fʊl.
Susan: Do you want something to drink?
ˈsuzən: du ju wɑnt ˈsʌmθɪŋ tu drɪŋk?
David: Yes, I\'d like some coffee.
ˈdeɪvɪd: jɛs, aɪd laɪk sʌm ˈkɑfi.
Susan: Sorry, I don\'t have any coffee.
ˈsuzən: ˈsɑri, aɪ doʊnt hæv ˈɛni ˈkɑfi.
David: That\'s OK. I\'ll have a glass of water.
ˈdeɪvɪd: ðæts ˈoʊˈkeɪ. aɪl hæv ə glæs ɑv ˈwɔtər.
Susan: A small glass, or a big one?
ˈsuzən: ə smɔl glæs, ɔr ə bɪg wʌn?
David: Small please.
ˈdeɪvɪd: smɔl pliz.
Susan: Here you are.
ˈsuzən: hir ju ɑr.
David: Thanks.
ˈdeɪvɪd: θæŋks.
Susan: You\'re welcome.
ˈsuzən: jʊr ˈwɛlkəm.
\n
UNIT 7: THAT\'S TOO LATE.
ˈjunət 7: ðæts tu leɪt.
Richard: Mary, would you like to get something to eat with me?
ˈrɪʧɜrd: ˈmɛri, wʊd ju laɪk tu gɛt ˈsʌmθɪŋ tu it wɪð mi?
Mary: OK. When?
ˈmɛri: ˈoʊˈkeɪ. wɛn?
Richard: At 10 o\'clock.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: æt 10 əˈklɑk.
Mary: 10 in the morning?
ˈmɛri: 10 ɪn ðə ˈmɔrnɪŋ?
Richard: No, at night.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: noʊ, æt naɪt.
Mary: Sorry, that\'s too late. I usually go to bed around 10:00.
ˈmɛri: ˈsɑri, ðæts tu leɪt. aɪ ˈjuʒəwəli goʊ tu bɛd əˈraʊnd 10:00.
Richard: OK, how about 1:30
ˈrɪʧɜrd: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, haʊ əˈbaʊt 1:30
Mary: No, that\'s too early. I\'ll still be at work then.
ˈmɛri: noʊ, ðæts tu ˈɜrli. aɪl stɪl bi æt wɜrk ðɛn.
Richard: How about 5:00?
ˈrɪʧɜrd: haʊ əˈbaʊt 5:00?
Mary: That\'s fine.
ˈmɛri: ðæts faɪn.
Richard: OK, see you then.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, si ju ðɛn.
Mary: Alright. Bye.
ˈmɛri: ˌɔlˈraɪt. baɪ.
\n
UNIT 8: CHOOSING A TIME TO MEET.
ˈjunət 8: ˈʧuzɪŋ ə taɪm tu mit.
Charles: Jennifer, would you like to have dinner with me?
ʧɑrlz: ˈʤɛnəfər, wʊd ju laɪk tu hæv ˈdɪnər wɪð mi?
Jennifer: Yes. That would be nice. When do you want to go?
ˈʤɛnəfər: jɛs. ðæt wʊd bi naɪs. wɛn du ju wɑnt tu goʊ?
Charles: Is today OK?
ʧɑrlz: ɪz təˈdeɪ ˈoʊˈkeɪ?
Jennifer: Sorry, I can\'t go today.
ˈʤɛnəfər: ˈsɑri, aɪ kænt goʊ təˈdeɪ.
Charles: How about tomorrow night?
ʧɑrlz: haʊ əˈbaʊt təˈmɑˌroʊ naɪt?
Jennifer: Ok. What time?
ˈʤɛnəfər: ˈoʊˈkeɪ. wʌt taɪm?
Charles: Is 9:00 all right?
ʧɑrlz: ɪz 9:00 ɔl raɪt?
Jennifer: I think that\'s too late.
ˈʤɛnəfər: aɪ θɪŋk ðæts tu leɪt.
Charles: Is 6:00 OK?
ʧɑrlz: ɪz 6:00 ˈoʊˈkeɪ?
Jennifer: Yes, that\'s good. Where would you like to go?
ˈʤɛnəfər: jɛs, ðæts gʊd. wɛr wʊd ju laɪk tu goʊ?
Charles: The Italian restaurant on 5th street.
ʧɑrlz: ði ɪˈtæljən ˈrɛstəˌrɑnt ɑn 5ˈtiˈeɪʧ strit.
Jennifer: Oh, I don\'t like that Restaurant. I don\'t want to go there.
ˈʤɛnəfər: oʊ, aɪ doʊnt laɪk ðæt ˈrɛstəˌrɑnt. aɪ doʊnt wɑnt tu goʊ ðeər.
Charles: How about the Korean restaurant next to it?
ʧɑrlz: haʊ əˈbaʊt ðə kɔˈriən ˈrɛstəˌrɑnt nɛkst tu ɪt?
Jennifer: OK, I like that place.
ˈʤɛnəfər: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, aɪ laɪk ðæt pleɪs.
\n
UNIT 9: WHEN DO YOU WANT TO GO?
ˈjunət 9: wɛn du ju wɑnt tu goʊ?
Linda: Hi Mark.
ˈlɪndə: haɪ mɑrk.
Mark: Hi.
mɑrk: haɪ.
Linda: What are you planning to do today?
ˈlɪndə: wʌt ɑr ju ˈplænɪŋ tu du təˈdeɪ?
Mark: I\'m not sure yet.
mɑrk: aɪm nɑt ʃʊr jɛt.
Linda: Would you like to have lunch with me?
ˈlɪndə: wʊd ju laɪk tu hæv lʌnʧ wɪð mi?
Mark: Yes. When?
mɑrk: jɛs. wɛn?
Linda: Is it 11:30 OK?
ˈlɪndə: ɪz ɪt 11:30 ˈoʊˈkeɪ?
Mark: Sorry, I didn\'t hear you. Can you say that again please?
mɑrk: ˈsɑri, aɪ ˈdɪdənt hir ju. kæn ju seɪ ðæt əˈgɛn pliz?
Linda: I said, 11:30.
ˈlɪndə: aɪ sɛd, 11:30.
Mark: Oh, I\'m busy then. Can we meet a little later?
mɑrk: oʊ, aɪm ˈbɪzi ðɛn. kæn wi mit ə ˈlɪtəl ˈleɪtər?
Linda: OK, how about 12:30?
ˈlɪndə: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, haʊ əˈbaʊt 12:30?
Mark: OK. Where?
mɑrk: ˈoʊˈkeɪ. wɛr?
Linda: How about Bill\'s Seafood Restaurant?
ˈlɪndə: haʊ əˈbaʊt bɪlz ˈsiˌfud ˈrɛstəˌrɑnt?
Mark: Oh, Where is that?
mɑrk: oʊ, wɛr ɪz ðæt?
Linda: It\'s on 7th Street.
ˈlɪndə: ɪts ɑn 7ˈtiˈeɪʧ strit.
Mark: OK, I\'ll meet you there.
mɑrk: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, aɪl mit ju ðeər.
\n
UNIT 10: ORDERING FOOD.
ˈjunət 10: ˈɔrdərɪŋ fud.
Host: Hello sir, welcome to the French Garden Restaurant. How many?
hoʊst: həˈloʊ sɜr, ˈwɛlkəm tu ðə frɛnʧ ˈgɑrdən ˈrɛstəˌrɑnt. haʊ ˈmɛni?
Charles: 1
ʧɑrlz: 1
Host: Right this way. Please have a seat. Your waitress will be with you in a moment.
hoʊst: raɪt ðɪs weɪ. pliz hæv ə sit. jʊər ˈweɪtrəs wɪl bi wɪð ju ɪn ə ˈmoʊmənt.
Waitress: Hello sir, would you like to order now?
ˈweɪtrəs: həˈloʊ sɜr, wʊd ju laɪk tu ˈɔrdər naʊ?
Charles: Yes please.
ʧɑrlz: jɛs pliz.
Waitress: What would you like to drink?
ˈweɪtrəs: wʌt wʊd ju laɪk tu drɪŋk?
Charles: What do you have?
ʧɑrlz: wʌt du ju hæv?
Waitress: We have bottled water, juice, and Coke.
ˈweɪtrəs: wi hæv ˈbɑtəld ˈwɔtər, ʤus, ænd koʊk.
Charles: I\'ll have a bottle of water please.
ʧɑrlz: aɪl hæv ə ˈbɑtəl ɑv ˈwɔtər pliz.
Waitress: What would you like to eat?
ˈweɪtrəs: wʌt wʊd ju laɪk tu it?
Charles: I\'ll have a tuna fish sandwich and a bowl of vegetable soup.
ʧɑrlz: aɪl hæv ə ˈtunə fɪʃ ˈsændwɪʧ ænd ə boʊl ɑv ˈvɛʤtəbəl sup.
\n
UNIT 11: NOW OR LATER?
ˈjunət 11: naʊ ɔr ˈleɪtər?
Elizabeth: Chris, where are you going?
ɪˈlɪzəbəθ: krɪs, wɛr ɑr ju ˈgoʊɪŋ?
Chris: I\'m going to the store
krɪs: aɪm ˈgoʊɪŋ tu ðə stɔr
Elizabeth: Really? I need to go to the store too.
ɪˈlɪzəbəθ: ˈrɪli? aɪ nid tu goʊ tu ðə stɔr tu.
Chris: Would you like to come with me?
krɪs: wʊd ju laɪk tu kʌm wɪð mi?
Elizabeth: Yeah, let\'s go together.
ɪˈlɪzəbəθ: jæ, lɛts goʊ təˈgɛðər.
Chris: Would you like to go now or later?
krɪs: wʊd ju laɪk tu goʊ naʊ ɔr ˈleɪtər?
Elizabeth: Now.
ɪˈlɪzəbəθ: naʊ.
Chris: What?
krɪs: wʌt?
Elizabeth: Now would be better.
ɪˈlɪzəbəθ: naʊ wʊd bi ˈbɛtər.
Chris: OK, let\'s go.
krɪs: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, lɛts goʊ.
Elizabeth: Should we walk?
ɪˈlɪzəbəθ: ʃʊd wi wɔk?
Chris: No, it\'s too far. Let\'s drive.
krɪs: noʊ, ɪts tu fɑr. lɛts draɪv.
\n
UNIT 12: DO YOU HAVE ENOUGH MONEY?
ˈjunət 12: du ju hæv ɪˈnʌf ˈmʌni?
Joe: Laura, what are you going to do today?
ʤoʊ: ˈlɔrə, wʌt ɑr ju ˈgoʊɪŋ tu du təˈdeɪ?
Laura: I\'m going shopping.
ˈlɔrə: aɪm ˈgoʊɪŋ ˈʃɑpɪŋ.
Joe: What time are you leaving?
ʤoʊ: wʌt taɪm ɑr ju ˈlivɪŋ?
Laura: I\'m going to leave around 4 o\'clock.
ˈlɔrə: aɪm ˈgoʊɪŋ tu liv əˈraʊnd 4 əˈklɑk.
Joe: Will you buy a ham sandwich for me at the store?
ʤoʊ: wɪl ju baɪ ə hæm ˈsændwɪʧ fɔr mi æt ðə stɔr?
Laura: OK.
ˈlɔrə: ˈoʊˈkeɪ.
Joe: Do you have enough money?
ʤoʊ: du ju hæv ɪˈnʌf ˈmʌni?
Laura: I\'m not sure.
ˈlɔrə: aɪm nɑt ʃʊr.
Joe: How much do you have?
ʤoʊ: haʊ mʌʧ du ju hæv?
Laura: 25 dollars. Do you think that\'s enough?
ˈlɔrə: 25 ˈdɑlɜrz. du ju θɪŋk ðæts ɪˈnʌf?
Joe: That\'s not very much.
ʤoʊ: ðæts nɑt ˈvɛri mʌʧ.
Laura: I think it\'s OK. I also have 2 credit cards.
ˈlɔrə: aɪ θɪŋk ɪts ˈoʊˈkeɪ. aɪ ˈɔlsoʊ hæv 2 ˈkrɛdət kɑrdz.
Joe: Let me give you another 10 dollars.
ʤoʊ: lɛt mi gɪv ju əˈnʌðər 10 ˈdɑlɜrz.
Laura: Thanks. See you later.
ˈlɔrə: θæŋks. si ju ˈleɪtər.
Joe: Bye
ʤoʊ: baɪ
\n
UNIT 13: HOW HAVE YOU BEEN?
ˈjunət 13: haʊ hæv ju bɪn?
Karen: Hello Richard.
ˈkɛrən: həˈloʊ ˈrɪʧɜrd.
Richard: Hi Karen.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: haɪ ˈkɛrən.
Karen: How have you been?
ˈkɛrən: haʊ hæv ju bɪn?
Richard: Not too good.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: nɑt tu gʊd.
Karen: Why?
ˈkɛrən: waɪ?
Richard: I\'m sick.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: aɪm sɪk.
Karen: Sorry to hear that.
ˈkɛrən: ˈsɑri tu hir ðæt.
Richard: It\'s OK. It\'s not serious.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: ɪts ˈoʊˈkeɪ. ɪts nɑt ˈsɪriəs.
Karen: That\'s good. How\'s your wife?
ˈkɛrən: ðæts gʊd. haʊz jʊər waɪf?
Richard: She\'s good
ˈrɪʧɜrd: ʃiz gʊd
Karen: Is she in America now?
ˈkɛrən: ɪz ʃi ɪn əˈmɛrəkə naʊ?
Richard: No, she\'s not here yet.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: noʊ, ʃiz nɑt hir jɛt.
Karen: Where is she?
ˈkɛrən: wɛr ɪz ʃi?
Richard: She\'s in Canada with our kids.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: ʃiz ɪn ˈkænədə wɪð ˈaʊər kɪdz.
Karen: I see. I have to go now. Please tell your wife I said hi.
ˈkɛrən: aɪ si. aɪ hæv tu goʊ naʊ. pliz tɛl jʊər waɪf aɪ sɛd haɪ.
Richard: OK, I\'ll talk to you later.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, aɪl tɔk tu ju ˈleɪtər.
Karen: I hope you feel better.
ˈkɛrən: aɪ hoʊp ju fil ˈbɛtər.
Richard: Thanks.
ˈrɪʧɜrd: θæŋks.
\n
UNIT 14: INTRODUCING A FRIEND.
ˈjunət 14: ˌɪntrəˈdusɪŋ ə frɛnd.
Michael: Robert, this is my friend, Mrs. Smith.
ˈmaɪkəl: ˈrɑbɜrt, ðɪs ɪz maɪ frɛnd, ˈmɪsɪz. smɪθ.
Robert: Hi, Nice to meet you.
ˈrɑbɜrt: haɪ, naɪs tu mit ju.
Mrs. Smith: Nice to meet you too.
ˈmɪsɪz. smɪθ: naɪs tu mit ju tu.
Robert: Mrs. Smith, what do you do for work?
ˈrɑbɜrt: ˈmɪsɪz. smɪθ, wʌt du ju du fɔr wɜrk?

daɪˈæn: ðæt saʊndz gʊd. dɪd ju ˈstʌdi ˈkʊkɪŋ ɪn skul?

ˈpætrɪk: noʊ, aɪ lɜrnd baɪ ˌmaɪˈsɛlf. aɪ hæv ə gʊd kʊk bʊk ðæt aɪ rid wɛn aɪ hæv taɪm.
\n
UNIT 42: HELPING A FRIEND MOVE.
ˈjunət 42: ˈhɛlpɪŋ ə frɛnd muv.
Peter: Kelly, will you help me take these things to the car?
ˈpitər: ˈkɛli, wɪl ju hɛlp mi teɪk ðiz θɪŋz tu ðə kɑr?
Kelly: OK, which car do you want me to put them in?
ˈkɛli: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, wɪʧ kɑr du ju wɑnt mi tu pʊt ðɛm ɪn?
Peter: Bring them to my wife\'s car.
ˈpitər: brɪŋ ðɛm tu maɪ waɪfs kɑr.
Kelly: Which one is hers\'?
ˈkɛli: wɪʧ wʌn ɪz hɜrz?
Peter: The blue SUV in front of the Honda.
ˈpitər: ðə blu ɛs-ju-vi ɪn frʌnt ɑv ðə ˈhɔndə.
Kelly: What should I take first?
ˈkɛli: wʌt ʃʊd aɪ teɪk fɜrst?
Peter: That chair over there, but please be careful with it. It was a gift from my mother-in-law.
ˈpitər: ðæt ʧɛr ˈoʊvər ðeər, bʌt pliz bi ˈkɛrfəl wɪð ɪt. ɪt wʌz ə gɪft frʌm maɪ ˈmʌðərɪnˌlɔ.
Kelly: Don\'t worry, I won\'t drop it. Wow, it\'s really heavy. I don\'t think I can move it by myself.
ˈkɛli: doʊnt ˈwɜri, aɪ woʊnt drɑp ɪt. waʊ, ɪts ˈrɪli ˈhɛvi. aɪ doʊnt θɪŋk aɪ kæn muv ɪt baɪ ˌmaɪˈsɛlf.
Peter: Let me help you with that. I don\'t want you to hurt your back.
ˈpitər: lɛt mi hɛlp ju wɪð ðæt. aɪ doʊnt wɑnt ju tu hɜrt jʊər bæk.
Kelly: Where are you taking off this stuff?
ˈkɛli: wɛr ɑr ju ˈteɪkɪŋ ɔf ðɪs stʌf?
Peter: Didn\'t I tell you? We\'re moving to Florida?
ˈpitər: ˈdɪdənt aɪ tɛl ju? wir ˈmuvɪŋ tu ˈflɔrədə?
Kelly: You\'re moving now? I knew you were moving, but I thought you said you were moving next month.
ˈkɛli: jʊr ˈmuvɪŋ naʊ? aɪ nu ju wɜr ˈmuvɪŋ, bʌt aɪ θɔt ju sɛd ju wɜr ˈmuvɪŋ nɛkst mʌnθ.
Peter: Yes, that\'s true, but my wife found a new apartment on the Internet the other day and she wants to move right away.
ˈpitər: jɛs, ðæts tru, bʌt maɪ waɪf faʊnd ə nu əˈpɑrtmənt ɑn ði ˈɪntərˌnɛt ði ˈʌðər deɪ ænd ʃi wɑnts tu muv raɪt əˈweɪ.
\n
UNIT 43: VISITING FAMILY.
ˈjunət 43: ˈvɪzətɪŋ ˈfæməli.
Henry: Judy, your husband has a really nice car.
ˈhɛnri: ˈʤudi, jʊər ˈhʌzbənd hæz ə ˈrɪli naɪs kɑr.
Judy: Thanks. It\'s a lot better than mine, and it\'s new.
ˈʤudi: θæŋks. ɪts ə lɑt ˈbɛtər ðæn maɪn, ænd ɪts nu.
Henry: Where are you going?
ˈhɛnri: wɛr ɑr ju ˈgoʊɪŋ?
Judy: We\'re going to visit my sister in the city.
ˈʤudi: wir ˈgoʊɪŋ tu ˈvɪzət maɪ ˈsɪstər ɪn ðə ˈsɪti.
Henry: I didn\'t know your sister lives in the city, when did she move there?
ˈhɛnri: aɪ ˈdɪdənt noʊ jʊər ˈsɪstər lɪvz ɪn ðə ˈsɪti, wɛn dɪd ʃi muv ðeər?
Judy: About a year ago. She lives in an apartment on 3rd street, across from the public library.
ˈʤudi: əˈbaʊt ə jɪr əˈgoʊ. ʃi lɪvz ɪn ən əˈpɑrtmənt ɑn 3rd strit, əˈkrɔs frʌm ðə ˈpʌblɪk ˈlaɪˌbrɛri.
Henry: I see. It\'s almost 5:00 now, don\'t you think there will be a lot of traffic?
ˈhɛnri: aɪ si. ɪts ˈɔlˌmoʊst 5:00 naʊ, doʊnt ju θɪŋk ðeər wɪl bi ə lɑt ɑv ˈtræfɪk?
Judy: Oh, we\'re not driving. We\'re going to take the subway. The subway only takes about 20 minutes.
ˈʤudi: oʊ, wir nɑt ˈdraɪvɪŋ. wir ˈgoʊɪŋ tu teɪk ðə ˈsʌˌbweɪ. ðə ˈsʌˌbweɪ ˈoʊnli teɪks əˈbaʊt 20 ˈmɪnəts.
Henry: Yes, but it can be very crowded around this time. I always feel uncomfortable taking the subway.
ˈhɛnri: jɛs, bʌt ɪt kæn bi ˈvɛri ˈkraʊdəd əˈraʊnd ðɪs taɪm. aɪ ˈɔlˌweɪz fil ənˈkʌmfɜrtəbəl ˈteɪkɪŋ ðə ˈsʌˌbweɪ.
Judy: I take the subway to work every day, so I\'m used to it now.
ˈʤudi: aɪ teɪk ðə ˈsʌˌbweɪ tu wɜrk ˈɛvəri deɪ, soʊ aɪm juzd tu ɪt naʊ.
Henry: Doesn\'t your mother live in the city?
ˈhɛnri: ˈdʌzənt jʊər ˈmʌðər lɪv ɪn ðə ˈsɪti?
Judy: Yes, she\'s lived there for about 10 years.
ˈʤudi: jɛs, ʃiz laɪvd ðeər fɔr əˈbaʊt 10 jɪrz.
Henry: I remember when she moved there. Apartments were a lot cheaper then.
ˈhɛnri: aɪ rɪˈmɛmbər wɛn ʃi muvd ðeər. əˈpɑrtmənts wɜr ə lɑt ˈʧipər ðɛn.
Judy: I know what you mean. It\'s hard to find anything that\'s reasonable now.
ˈʤudi: aɪ noʊ wʌt ju min. ɪts hɑrd tu faɪnd ˈɛniˌθɪŋ ðæts ˈrizənəbəl naʊ.
Henry: Have a good time. Next time you\'re free, give me a call and we\'ll go play poker.
ˈhɛnri: hæv ə gʊd taɪm. nɛkst taɪm jʊr fri, gɪv mi ə kɔl ænd wil goʊ pleɪ ˈpoʊkər.
Judy: See you later.
ˈʤudi: si ju ˈleɪtər.
\n
UNIT 44: LOOKING AT VACATION PICTURES.
ˈjunət 44: ˈlʊkɪŋ æt veɪˈkeɪʃən ˈpɪkʧɜrz.
Kathy: Jim, I heard you took a trip to San Diego. Is that right?
ˈkæθi: ʤɪm, aɪ hɜrd ju tʊk ə trɪp tu sæn diˈeɪgoʊ. ɪz ðæt raɪt?
Jim: Yeah, I just got back this morning.
ʤɪm: jæ, aɪ ʤʌst gɑt bæk ðɪs ˈmɔrnɪŋ.
Kathy: That sounds really nice. What did you do there?
ˈkæθi: ðæt saʊndz ˈrɪli naɪs. wʌt dɪd ju du ðeər?
Jim: Well, we were only there for three days, so we didn\'t do too much. We went shopping and went out to dinner a few times. At night we walked around the city with some friends.
ʤɪm: wɛl, wi wɜr ˈoʊnli ðeər fɔr θri deɪz, soʊ wi ˈdɪdənt du tu mʌʧ. wi wɛnt ˈʃɑpɪŋ ænd wɛnt aʊt tu ˈdɪnər ə fju taɪmz. æt naɪt wiwɔkt əˈraʊnd ðə ˈsɪti wɪð sʌm frɛndz.
Kathy: Did you take any pictures?
ˈkæθi: dɪd ju teɪk ˈɛni ˈpɪkʧɜrz?
Jim: Yes, I have them with me. Do you want to look at them?
ʤɪm: jɛs, aɪ hæv ðɛm wɪð mi. du ju wɑnt tu lʊk æt ðɛm?
Kathy: Sure, I love looking at photos.
ˈkæθi: ʃʊr, aɪ lʌv ˈlʊkɪŋ æt ˈfoʊˌtoʊz.
Jim: This one is of my wife and me on the beach, and this one is our daughter Emily standing next to my wife.
ʤɪm: ðɪs wʌn ɪz ɑv maɪ waɪf ænd mi ɑn ðə biʧ, ænd ðɪs wʌn ɪz ˈaʊər ˈdɔtər ˈɛmɪli ˈstændɪŋ nɛkst tu maɪ waɪf.
Kathy: Your daughter looks like her mother.
ˈkæθi: jʊər ˈdɔtər lʊks laɪk hɜr ˈmʌðər.
Jim: I know, they look very similar.
ʤɪm: aɪ noʊ, ðeɪ lʊk ˈvɛri ˈsɪmələr.
Kathy: Where was this picture taken?
ˈkæθi: wɛr wʌz ðɪs ˈpɪkʧər ˈteɪkən?
Jim: That was taken at the train station before we left.
ʤɪm: ðæt wʌz ˈteɪkən æt ðə treɪn ˈsteɪʃən bɪˈfɔr wi lɛft.
Kathy: Did you have time to go to the zoo?
ˈkæθi: dɪd ju hæv taɪm tu goʊ tu ðə zu?
Jim: No, not this time. We went there last time.
ʤɪm: noʊ, nɑt ðɪs taɪm. wi wɛnt ðeər læst taɪm.
Kathy: It looks like you all had a nice time.
ˈkæθi: ɪt lʊks laɪk ju ɔl hæd ə naɪs taɪm.
Jim: Yeah, it was a lot of fun.
ʤɪm: jæ, ɪt wʌz ə lɑt ɑv fʌn.
\n
UNIT 45: ORDERING FLOWERS.
ˈjunət 45: ˈɔrdərɪŋ ˈflaʊɜrz.
Receptionist: Good afternoon, how may I help you?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: gʊd ˌæftərˈnun, haʊ meɪ aɪ hɛlp ju?
Ryan: Hi, I\'d like to order some flowers.
ˈraɪən: haɪ, aɪd laɪk tu ˈɔrdər sʌm ˈflaʊɜrz.
Receptionist: Who are they for?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: hu ɑr ðeɪ fɔr?
Ryan: They\'re for my Wife. Her name is Samantha.
ˈraɪən: ðɛr fɔr maɪ waɪf. hɜr neɪm ɪz səˈmænθə.
Receptionist: What kind of flowers would you like?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: wʌt kaɪnd ɑv ˈflaʊɜrz wʊd ju laɪk?
Ryan: I don\'t know. I don\'t know too much about flowers. Can you recommend something?
ˈraɪən: aɪ doʊnt noʊ. aɪ doʊnt noʊ tu mʌʧ əˈbaʊt ˈflaʊɜrz. kæn ju ˌrɛkəˈmɛnd ˈsʌmθɪŋ?
Receptionist: OK. What\'s the reason you are sending her flowers?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: ˈoʊˈkeɪ. wʌts ðə ˈrizən ju ɑr ˈsɛndɪŋ hɜr ˈflaʊɜrz?
Ryan: Today\'s her birthday and she told me she wants me to buy her flowers.
ˈraɪən: təˈdeɪz hɜr ˈbɜrθˌdeɪ ænd ʃi toʊld mi ʃi wɑnts mi tu baɪ hɜr ˈflaʊɜrz.
Receptionist: Do you know what kind of flowers she likes?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: du ju noʊ wʌt kaɪnd ɑv ˈflaʊɜrz ʃi laɪks?
Ryan: I\'m not sure. I know I should know that, but I can\'t remember right now.
ˈraɪən: aɪm nɑt ʃʊr. aɪ noʊ aɪ ʃʊd noʊ ðæt, bʌt aɪ kænt rɪˈmɛmbər raɪt naʊ.
Receptionist: Well, they\'re for your wife, so I think you should give her roses.
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: wɛl, ðɛr fɔr jʊər waɪf, soʊ aɪ θɪŋk ju ʃʊd gɪv hɜr ˈroʊzɪz.
Ryan: Roses will be fine.
ˈraɪən: ˈroʊzɪz wɪl bi faɪn.
Receptionist: What color?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: wʌt ˈkʌlər?
Ryan: I think red would be nice.
ˈraɪən: aɪ θɪŋk rɛd wʊd bi naɪs.
Receptionist: Do you want to pick them up or should we deliver them?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: du ju wɑnt tu pɪk ðɛm ʌp ɔr ʃʊd wi dɪˈlɪvər ðɛm?
Ryan: Can you deliver them please.
ˈraɪən: kæn ju dɪˈlɪvər ðɛm pliz.
Receptionist: What\'s the address?
rɪˈsɛpʃənɪst: wʌts ði ˈæˌdrɛs?
Ryan: 241 Main street.
ˈraɪən: 241 meɪn strit.
\n
UNIT 46: LEAVING A MESSAGE.
ˈjunət 46: ˈlivɪŋ ə ˈmɛsəʤ.
Laura: Hello?
ˈlɔrə: həˈloʊ?
Jack: Hi, is Heather there please?
ʤæk: haɪ, ɪz ˈhɛðər ðeər pliz?
Laura: Sorry, I think you have the wrong number.
ˈlɔrə: ˈsɑri, aɪ θɪŋk ju hæv ðə rɔŋ ˈnʌmbər.
Jack: Is this 617-228-2289?
Laura: Yes. Who are you looking for again?
ˈlɔrə: jɛs. hu ɑr ju ˈlʊkɪŋ fɔr əˈgɛn?
Jack: Heather Johnson.
ʤæk: ˈhɛðər ˈʤɑnsən.
Laura: Oh, I thought you said Laura. Sorry about that. This is the right number, but Heather\'s not here right now.
ˈlɔrə: oʊ, aɪ θɔt ju sɛd ˈlɔrə. ˈsɑri əˈbaʊt ðæt. ðɪs ɪz ðə raɪt ˈnʌmbər, bʌt ˈhɛðɜrz nɑt hir raɪt naʊ.
Jack: Do you know where she went?
ʤæk: du ju noʊ wɛr ʃi wɛnt?
Laura: She went to the store to buy some groceries. Would you like to leave a message?
ˈlɔrə: ʃi wɛnt tu ðə stɔr tu baɪ sʌm ˈgroʊsəriz. wʊd ju laɪk tu liv ə ˈmɛsəʤ?
Jack: Yes, would you please tell her Eric Martin called?
ʤæk: jɛs, wʊd ju pliz tɛl hɜr ˈɛrɪk ˈmɑrtən kɔld?
Laura: Hi Eric, this is her roommate Kathy. I met you a couple months ago at the Christmas party.
ˈlɔrə: haɪ ˈɛrɪk, ðɪs ɪz hɜr ˈruˌmeɪt ˈkæθi. aɪ mɛt ju ə ˈkʌpəl mʌnθs əˈgoʊ æt ðə ˈkrɪsməs ˈpɑrti.
Jack: Oh, yes. How are you?
ʤæk: oʊ, jɛs. haʊ ɑr ju?
Laura: Good. Heather will be back in about 20 minutes. I\'ll tell her you called.
ˈlɔrə: gʊd. ˈhɛðər wɪl bi bæk ɪn əˈbaʊt 20 ˈmɪnəts. aɪl tɛl hɜr ju kɔld.
Jack: OK. Thanks.
ʤæk: ˈoʊˈkeɪ. θæŋks.
Laura: Bye bye.
ˈlɔrə: baɪ baɪ.
\n
UNIT 47: TALKING ABOUT THE WEATHER.
ˈjunət 47: ˈtɔkɪŋ əˈbaʊt ðə ˈwɛðər.
Tina: Hello?
ˈtinə: həˈloʊ?
Joe: Hi Tina, It\'s Joe.
ʤoʊ: haɪ ˈtinə, ɪts ʤoʊ.
Tina: Hi Joe.
ˈtinə: haɪ ʤoʊ.
Joe: How\'s the weather there today?
ʤoʊ: haʊz ðə ˈwɛðər ðeər təˈdeɪ?
Tina: It\'s really cold. It snowed all day and the schools closed early.
ˈtinə: ɪts ˈrɪli koʊld. ɪt snoʊd ɔl deɪ ænd ðə skulz kloʊzd ˈɜrli.
Joe: What\'s the temperature?
ʤoʊ: wʌts ðə ˈtɛmprəʧər?
Tina: It\'s 30 degrees now. It was even colder this morning.
ˈtinə: ɪts 30 dɪˈgriz naʊ. ɪt wʌz ˈivɪn ˈkoʊldər ðɪs ˈmɔrnɪŋ.
Joe: Have you heard what the weather is going to be like tomorrow?
ʤoʊ: hæv ju hɜrd wʌt ðə ˈwɛðər ɪz ˈgoʊɪŋ tu bi laɪk təˈmɑˌroʊ?
Tina: I was watching the news a little earlier. They said it\'s probably going to snow tomorrow.
ˈtinə: aɪ wʌz ˈwɑʧɪŋ ðə nuz ə ˈlɪtəl ˈɜrliər. ðeɪ sɛd ɪts ˈprɑbəbli ˈgoʊɪŋ tu snoʊ təˈmɑˌroʊ.
Joe: I really don\'t like the winter. I wish it were summer.
ʤoʊ: aɪ ˈrɪli doʊnt laɪk ðə ˈwɪntər. aɪ wɪʃ ɪt wɜr ˈsʌmər.
Tina: Me too. How\'s the weather where you are?
ˈtinə: mi tu. haʊz ðə ˈwɛðər wɛr ju ɑr?
Joe: It\'s not too bad, but it\'s pretty cold here too. It was about 45 today and it rained this afternoon. I heard it\'s going to be a little warmer tomorrow.
ʤoʊ: ɪts nɑt tu bæd, bʌt ɪts ˈprɪti koʊld hir tu. ɪt wʌz əˈbaʊt 45 təˈdeɪ ænd ɪt reɪnd ðɪs ˌæftərˈnun. aɪ hɜrd ɪts ˈgoʊɪŋ tu bi ə ˈlɪtəlˈwɔrmər təˈmɑˌroʊ.
\n
UNIT 48: MAKING PLANS.
ˈjunət 48: ˈmeɪkɪŋ plænz.
Tom: It\'s almost Christmas. What are you doing this weekend?
tɑm: ɪts ˈɔlˌmoʊst ˈkrɪsməs. wʌt ɑr ju ˈduɪŋ ðɪs ˈwiˌkɛnd?
Sara: Nothing special, just working. Why do you ask?
ˈsɛrə: ˈnʌθɪŋ ˈspɛʃəl, ʤʌst ˈwɜrkɪŋ. waɪ du ju æsk?
Tom: Well, I still haven\'t finished my Christmas shopping. Do you want to go shopping with me this weekend?
tɑm: wɛl, aɪ stɪl ˈhævənt ˈfɪnɪʃt maɪ ˈkrɪsməs ˈʃɑpɪŋ. du ju wɑnt tu goʊ ˈʃɑpɪŋ wɪð mi ðɪs ˈwiˌkɛnd?
Sara: I\'d like to, but I\'m not sure if I can. Work has been really busy lately. Why don\'t we go on Friday instead?
ˈsɛrə: aɪd laɪk tu, bʌt aɪm nɑt ʃʊr ɪf aɪ kæn. wɜrk hæz bɪn ˈrɪli ˈbɪzi ˈleɪtli. waɪ doʊnt wi goʊ ɑn ˈfraɪdi ɪnˈstɛd?
Tom: Friday\'s not good. I think the stores will be very crowded and I have to work.
tɑm: ˈfraɪdiz nɑt gʊd. aɪ θɪŋk ðə stɔrz wɪl bi ˈvɛri ˈkraʊdəd ænd aɪ hæv tu wɜrk.
Sara: OK, then let\'s try to go this weekend. I should know if I can go by Friday. Is it OK if I call you then?
ˈsɛrə: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, ðɛn lɛts traɪ tu goʊ ðɪs ˈwiˌkɛnd. aɪ ʃʊd noʊ ɪf aɪ kæn goʊ baɪ ˈfraɪdi. ɪz ɪt ˈoʊˈkeɪ ɪf aɪ kɔl ju ðɛn?
Tom: Yeah, that\'s fine.
tɑm: jæ, ðæts faɪn.
Sara: What\'s your number?
ˈsɛrə: wʌts jʊər ˈnʌmbər?
Tom: 223-331-8828. Let me give you my email address too. It\'s tom861@gmail.com
tɑm: 223-331-8828. lɛt mi gɪv ju maɪ iˈmeɪl ˈæˌdrɛs tu. ɪts tɑm861@gmail.kɑm
Sara: OK, I\'ll talk to you soon.
ˈsɛrə: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, aɪl tɔk tu ju sun.
Tom: OK.

UNIT 49: MEETING A FRIEND.

Vicky: Hello?

Ben: Hi Vicky.
bɛn: haɪ ˈvɪki.

Ben: Yes.
bɛn: jɛs.
Vicky: I just got off the subway. I\'m almost there. Sorry I\'m late.
ˈvɪki: aɪ ʤʌst gɑt ɔf ðə ˈsʌˌbweɪ. aɪm ˈɔlˌmoʊst ðeər. ˈsɑri aɪm leɪt.
Ben: That\'s no problem. I just wanted to tell you I\'m inside.
bɛn: ðæts noʊ ˈprɑbləm. aɪ ʤʌst ˈwɑntəd tu tɛl ju aɪm ɪnˈsaɪd.
Vicky: Where are you?
ˈvɪki: wɛr ɑr ju?
Ben: On the 2nd floor.
bɛn: ɑn ði 2nd flɔr.
Vicky: Should I come to the 2nd floor or do you want to come to the 1st floor?
ˈvɪki: ʃʊd aɪ kʌm tu ði 2nd flɔr ɔr du ju wɑnt tu kʌm tu ði 1strit flɔr?
Ben: Come upstairs.
bɛn: kʌm əpˈstɛrz.
Vicky: What?
ˈvɪki: wʌt?
Ben: Oh, Can you hear me OK? I said, come to the 2nd floor.
bɛn: oʊ, kæn ju hir mi ˈoʊˈkeɪ? aɪ sɛd, kʌm tu ði 2nd flɔr.
Vicky: Oh, OK. What are you doing there?
ˈvɪki: oʊ, ˈoʊˈkeɪ. wʌt ɑr ju ˈduɪŋ ðeər?
Ben: Just looking at some books on how to learn English.
bɛn: ʤʌst ˈlʊkɪŋ æt sʌm bʊks ɑn haʊ tu lɜrn ˈɪŋglɪʃ.
Vicky: Do you want to get something to eat later?
ˈvɪki: du ju wɑnt tu gɛt ˈsʌmθɪŋ tu it ˈleɪtər?
Ben: No, I\'m still full from dinner.
bɛn: noʊ, aɪm stɪl fʊl frʌm ˈdɪnər.
Vicky: What do you want to do?
ˈvɪki: wʌt du ju wɑnt tu du?
Ben: I don\'t know for sure. When you get here we\'ll talk about it.
bɛn: aɪ doʊnt noʊ fɔr ʃʊr. wɛn ju gɛt hir wil tɔk əˈbaʊt ɪt.
Vicky: OK, see you soon.
ˈvɪki: ˈoʊˈkeɪ, si ju sun.
Ben: Bye.
bɛn: baɪ.
